text.p: The following are the main stories from Friday morning's German newspapers:
FRANKFURTER ALLGEMEINE ZEITUNG
- More than 4.1 million unemployed, dark forecasts for joblessness in this year. Will 4.5 million soon be without jobs? Chancellor Helmut Kohl calls for reduction in overtime work hours.
- Kohl says there is no need to despair about economy. Says there are hopes for reduction in unemployment by year 2000. He says he is ready for new round of talks with unions and employers.

- German GDP grew only modestly in 1996, gaining 1.4 percent, slowed largely by decline in construction. Private consumption also weak. Important support for economy last year was export growth, which gained 4.6 percent.
- General Motors and Volkswagen want to reach an out of court deal to end dispute.
HANDELSBLATT
- VW and GM resolve legal dispute. Fears of escalation in the billion-mark conflict put aside. The bourse honours peace pact with share price surge for Volkswagen.

- EMU plans divides Germany into two camps. Poll finds 79 percent of Germans want a referrendum on EMU. Also finds narrow 44-43 percent edge against EMU. Poll done with The Daily Telegraph, Le Figaro and L'Expresso found support for euro strongest in Italy (71 percent), followed by France (61 percent), and weakest in Britain (26 percent).
- Economy in 1996 grew 1.4 percent.
- Kohl and unions signal willingness to move closer together again to combat unemployment.
SUEDDEUTSCHE ZEITUNG
- Kohl offers new round of talks with unions, employers to cut unemployment.
- Agreement reached between VW and GM.
DIE WELT
- Unemployment - Kohl hopes for economic upturn. Chancellor criticised companies, calls for cuts in overtime hours.
- GM and VW want to end dispute.
- SPD leader Rudolf Scharping says government has failed, Kohl leading Germany into economic and social catastrophe.
- Hollywood stars send open letter to Kohl criticising German for persecuting Scientologists.
-- Bonn Newsroom +49 228 26097160
